I.  THE ONGOING PROJECT 
 
1.  Since 2012, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has engaged with the Government of 
Myanmar to help formulate and implement education reforms, particularly in secondary education 
and  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training  (TVET).  The  Equipping  Youth  for 
Employment  Project  (EYE)—the  first  ADB  loan  for  Myanmar’s  education  sector—aims  to 
strengthen the country’s education and skills base and promote inclusive growth and job creation.1 
The EYE supports reforms to realign secondary education and TVET to Myanmar’s evolving 
workforce needs. These reforms are vital to equip youth with skills for employment in a modern 
economy and meet employers’ skill demands. The project’s impact will be education and skills 
base for inclusive growth enhanced, and its outcome will be secondary education subsector and 
TVET realigned to evolving labor force needs and equitably expanded. The EYE has three outputs: 
(i) policy frameworks and capacities for cohesive, workforce-responsive secondary education 
subsector and TVET enhanced; (ii) new secondary education subsector curriculum delivered and 
access expanded; and (iii) new TVET programs introduced and access expanded. The project’s 
total cost is $105.0 million, with $98.5 million financed by a loan from ADB.2  
 
2.  ADB and the European Union (EU) have been closely collaborating with the Ministry of 
Education (MOE) and other development partners to design and implement education reforms, 
focusing strategically on secondary education and TVET.3 In 2019, the EU and the Government 
of Myanmar signed the financing agreement for  Education Sector Reform Contract with grant 
financing of up to €221 million, including budget support of €175 million for secondary education 
and  TVET  reforms  and  complementary  measures. 4  The  proposed  transaction  technical 
assistance (TA) will support a subset of the complementary measures. Enhancing ongoing ADB 
(EYE) and EU support, the EU will finance the proposed TA in the amount of €24 million ($26.0 
million equivalent) and ADB will administer it. The TA will support continued reforms to better align 
secondary education and TVET to Myanmar’s evolving skill demands. The TA aligns with ADB’s 
Myanmar country partnership strategy, 2017-2021, that focuses on strengthening human capital 
to  promote  a  skilled  workforce  and  increased  employment,  and  enable  the  poor  and 
disadvantaged to benefit from economic growth.5 It also aligns with ADB’s Strategy 2030 and will 
help address remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by improving education and training 
(operational priority 1) and accelerate progress in gender equality (operational priority 2).6  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Weak human capital poses a critical obstacle to Myanmar’s development, threatening to 
trap the economy in a low value-added model based on cheap, unskilled labor and natural 
 
1  ADB. Myanmar: Equipping Youth for Employment Project.  
2  As of 30 September 2019, cumulative contract awards reached $20.9 and disbursements reached $13.3 million. The 
project is rated an actual problem as of September 2019 because of startup delays. Implementation progress has 
improved, and thus project rating is expected to improve in 2020 after the midterm review. 
3  Development partner support for education in Myanmar is concentrated in primary education, while ADB and EU 
provide the main international support for secondary education and TVET.   
4  European Commission. International Cooperation and Development. https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/annual-action-
programme-2018-part-1-favour-myanmarburma_en.    
5  ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2017-2021–Building the Foundations for Inclusive Growth. 
Manila. 
6  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila.

2 
resource exploitation, while obstructing national poverty reduction and inclusive growth goals.7 
Many young entrants to the workforce lack skills needed for employment in a modern economy.8 
Employers consistently cite weak human capital as a leading constraint on business.9 Secondary 
education and TVET are central to this human capital challenge. Secondary education supplies 
the largest share (50%) of entrants into nonagricultural formal wage labor. However, outdated 
curricula  and  rote-based  teaching  and  learning  approaches  mean  that  school-leavers  lack 
foundation skills (e.g., literacy and numeracy) and soft skills (e.g., critical thinking, problem-solving, 
creativity, and communication skills). Likewise, TVET has struggled to equip youth with vocation-
specific hard skills (e.g., construction or mechanical skills) and with entrepreneurship and other 
business-related  skills. To  address  these  challenges, the MOE  initiated  reforms  under  the 
National Education Strategic Plan, 2016–2021 to realign secondary education and TVET to meet 
evolving labor market skill needs. However, reversing decades of underinvestment will require 
sustained support. ADB and the EU are committed to support sequenced reforms under the 
current National Education Strategic Plan and any subsequent national plans.  
 
4.  The EYE is providing introduction training of the new curriculum which will not be sufficient 
for teachers to change their teaching and learning practice. It is supporting the introduction of 
competency-based modular short courses at selected public TVET schools which require further 
expansion to meet demands from industry. Building on key initial reforms supported by EYE and 
complementing the budget support provided by the EU (para 2), the proposed TA will support the 
MOE in advancing critical follow-on reforms. First, it will strengthen MOE capacity to formulate 
and implement cohesive and evidence-based reforms to align skill supply with evolving skill 
demand. Second, as part of a multipronged approach to improve teaching and learning, the TA 
will support the MOE to formulate and introduce (i) a continuing professional development (CPD) 
system  for  in-service  secondary  education teachers  and  (ii)  updated pre-service  education 
programs to prepare future high school teachers to deliver the new curriculum. This will enhance 
the MOE’s overhaul of the secondary education curriculum (including textbooks and teacher 
guides) and annual rounds of in-service training of teachers to deliver the improved curriculum 
supported under EYE.10 Third, the TA will provide follow-on support to the MOE to (i) reform 
curricula of longer-term TVET programs at upper secondary and post-secondary levels; and (ii) 
strengthen MOE cooperation with nongovernment organizations and industries to diversify TVET 
provision, including targeting females and ethnic group youth. The TA will also feed into a potential 
second phase of EYE.11  
 
 
7  S. D’Amico, C. Spohr, and S. Tanaka. 2015. Myanmar Human Capital Development, Employment, and Labor 
Markets. ADB Economics Working Paper Series. No. 469. Manila: ADB.   
8   Females are particularly likely to be trapped in vulnerable employment: 53% of working females age 20–29 are own 
account or contributing family workers, versus 47% for their male counterparts. 
9  Myanmar’s Private Sector Development Framework and Action Plan identifies human capital as a core priority: 
http://www.dica.gov.mm/sites/dica.gov.mm/files/document-files/psd_framework_final_01_apr_englidh.pdf.   
10  In May 2019, EYE provided 14 days of in-service teacher training to support introduction of the new grade 6 
curriculum, with further annual rounds planned for 2020–2022 to support introduction of the new curriculum for grades 
7 to 12.  
11  The proposed provision of a transaction technical assistance (TA) after the approval of EYE reflects (i) signing of the 
financing agreement of EU’s assistance program with the Government of Myanmar in February 2019 (para. 2), (ii) 
the technical nature of support, and (iii) EU preference for the TA modality in lieu of project grant modality, which 
would require administration by the MOE.

3 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
5.  The  TA  will  have  three  outputs,  as  outlined  below  and  elaborated  in  the  terms  of 
reference.12 
 
6.  Output 1: Evidence-based post-primary education reforms effectively supported, 
monitored, and disseminated. The TA will provide cohesive and crosscutting umbrella support 
for post-primary education (focusing on secondary education and TVET) to align with evolving 
labor market demands for foundation skills, soft skills, and technical and vocational skills. In 
particular,  it  will  support  (i)  analysis,  evidence-based  planning,  and  crosscutting  capacity 
development,  focusing  on  post-primary  education  reform,  and  (ii)  TA-wide  coordination, 
monitoring and evaluation, gender actions, and communication.   
 
7.  Analytical and evidence-based planning and capacity development. First, the TA will 
support  the  MOE  to  consolidate  and  analyze  data  from  various  sources  (including  via 
collaboration with the Ministry of Labour, Immigration, and Population) on skill supply and evolving 
skill  demands,  including  disaggregation  by  gender,  geographic  areas,  and  other  social 
dimensions.13 It will develop bilingual (Myanmar language and English) knowledge products 
distilling national and international analysis and experience. Second, the TA will help the MOE 
translate national analysis and international experience into the national education plan’s next 
phase (2021–2026) and longer-term skills development strategies for Myanmar to  improve 
regional and global competitiveness. It will support Myanmar’s hosting of and participation in 
international forums to bring insights from global practices to Myanmar’s key reforms. Third, the 
TA will support MOE capacities in engaging stakeholders at central to grassroot levels (e.g., local 
governments, the private sector, civil society groups working with female and ethnic group youth, 
and  private  education  and  training  providers)  in  reform-related  dialogue.  It  will  enhance 
coordination mechanisms, including the government–industry Working Committee on Human 
Capital,  and  effective  use  of  affordable  digital  technology,  information,  education,  and 
communication tools for dissemination and social marketing of key reforms.14  
 
8.  Support  for  TA-wide  coordination,  monitoring  and  evaluation,  gender  actions, 
communication,  and  administration.  The  TA  will  help  ensure  strong  ownership  and 
coordination across all outputs with relevant departments of the MOE. It will also support 
monitoring and evaluation across all initiatives (including disaggregation by sex, ethnic group, and 
other dimensions), gender actions, communication plan implementation, other crosscutting work, 
and the TA-financed procurement of goods (e.g., learning materials and minor equipment).  
 
9.  Output 2: New secondary education continuing professional development system 
and pre-service teacher education program introduced. The TA will support the introduction 
of two critical reforms to improve teaching and learning outcomes in secondary education: (i) a 
 
12 The terms of reference for consultants are accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. EYE’s design 
and monitoring framework will be updated upon approval of the proposed TA during the midterm review of EYE, to 
reflect the key activities of the TA. The updated design and monitoring framework will be included in the project 
administration manual.  
13  Such data sources include the MOE’s Education Management Information System, the November 2019 Intercensal 
Survey, and the periodic Labor Force Survey. The TA will build on initial ADB-supported geographic information 
system mapping of school networks and employment patterns.  
14 The Working Committee on Human Capital was established to support implementation of the human capital pillar of 
the Private Sector Development Framework and Action Plan (footnote 7) and is chaired by the MOE Deputy Minister. 
The TA may also support the proposed TVET Council (expected to be established by 2021) in promoting TVET-
focused coordination.

4 
school-based CPD system and (ii) upgraded pre-service education programs for future high 
school teachers. The TA will enhance EYE-supported introduction of new textbooks, teacher 
guides, and annual teacher training rounds, and will build on EU support for school-based CPD 
module development.  
 
10.  Continuous professional development for in-service secondary education teachers. 
The TA will build on the ongoing EYE and EU support to introduce basic CPD activities for middle 
school teachers linked to the rollout of the revised grade 6 curriculum in school year (SY) 2019/20. 
First, it will support capacity building at the central to school level to manage and deliver CPD 
linked to the remainder of curriculum reforms, including extending high school through grade 12 
in SY2022/23.15 Second, it will support digital technology and media-based materials to support 
CPD, which will be sensitive to gender and  ethnic group. Third, the TA will support development 
and institutionalization of a national CPD system to provide continued local and in-school support 
to teachers after the completion of ongoing curriculum reforms in SY2022/23. CPD programs will 
ensure equitable access to female and ethnic group teachers. 
 
11.  Upgraded pre-service teacher education for future high school teachers. First, the 
TA will help the MOE revise the curriculum for Bachelor of Education programs for future high 
school teachers to align with the forthcoming 3-year (grades 10–12) high school curriculum.16 
New curricula will be sensitive to gender and ethnic group. Second, the TA will enhance the 
professional skills and competencies of teacher educators at the three universities offering the 
Bachelor of Education programs.17 Third, the TA will strengthen the Bachelor of Education 
programs’ management and quality assurance. The TA will help these three universities to forge 
twinning arrangements with international teacher education institutions to establish long-term 
partnerships to strengthen research capacity and teacher education management.  
 
12.  Output 3: Technical vocational education and training programs diversified and 
better  aligned  with  evolving  labor  market  demands.  The  TA  will  support  the  MOE  in 
accelerating reforms to improve TVET quality and relevance; diversify TVET offerings; and 
expand TVET access, including for female students, disadvantaged youth, and underserved 
areas. Enhancing EYE and EU support, the TA will support longer-term TVET program reforms 
and new partnerships in TVET provision.  
 
13.  Development  of  revised  curricula  for  government  technical  high  schools  and 
government technical institutes. The TA will support MOE’s introduction of new curricula for 
government technical high schools and government technical institutes to better align with skill 
demands from industries. This includes capacity development of trainers in partnerships with 
industry, and procurement of the required materials and equipment to support preparation and 
initial roll-out of the revised TVET curricula. Social marketing will aim to attract more females into 
TVET, especially to nontraditional skill areas (e.g., manufacturing and electrical works). The TA 
will help the MOE to develop a strategic plan on infrastructure, equipment, and materials for the 
revised TVET programs, to be financed by government budget and/or international support.  
 
14.  Expansion of technical vocational education and training partnerships. The TA will 
help the MOE expand strategic partnerships with international nongovernment organizations 
 
15 Following the MOE’s introduction of a new kindergarten year in SY2016/17, the extension of high school (upper 
secondary) through grade 12 (supported by EYE) in SY2022/23 will bring Myanmar up to international norm of a 
kindergarten–12 system.   
16 These include a 5-year program for high school graduates and a 2-year program to upgrade middle school teachers. 
17 These are Yangon University of Education, Sagaing University of Education, and University of Development of 
National Races.

5 
(INGOs) and the private sector to diversify short-term TVET programs to include additional skill 
areas and reach more youth and workers, including females and males in underserved areas 
(including areas with large ethnic group populations). First, the TA will help the MOE collaborate 
with INGOs and local partners to extend TVET short courses, through harmonizing approaches, 
ensuring quality control, and facilitating issuance of completion certificates by the MOE. The TA 
will support competitive tendering of INGOs to provide short courses in selected high priority skill 
and geographic areas to open more room for INGOs to operate effectively in Myanmar’s TVET 
sector.18 Second, in coordination with the government–industry Working Committee on Human 
Capital, the TA will support the MOE to expand MOE–industry collaboration in reskilling and 
upskilling  youth  and  existing  workers.  This  will  include  support  to  (i)  develop  operational 
guidelines for training organized jointly by public TVET schools and private sector entities, and (ii) 
pilot a training partnership fund to cover eligible costs for the training. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $26.1 million, of which $26.0 million (not exceeding €24.0 
million) will be financed on a grant basis by the EU and administered by ADB. The key expenditure 
items are listed in Appendix 1. Indicatively, output 1 is estimated to cost $5.1 million, output 2 is 
estimated  at  $7.3  million,  and  output  3  is  estimated  at  $10.7  million.  In  addition,  ADB 
administration cost, contingencies, and audit cost are estimated at $2.9 million. The Government 
of Myanmar will provide the balance in the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation for 
selected consultants, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
16.  The EU grant will finance the TA activities and outputs, including operational expenses, in 
the form of consulting services, trainings, workshops, conferences, modest goods procurement 
such as to support preparation and initial roll out of revised TVET curricula, as well as audit and 
administration costs.19 The TA will not be used for civil works.    
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  ADB will administer the TA. The Human and Social Development Division, Southeast Asia 
Department  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  TA-financed  consultants,  and  will  monitor 
procurement of goods by the TA-financed consultants. The MOE will be the executing agency 
and the MOE Executive Committee will provide oversight with the relevant focal departments. 
 
18.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table below. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative  January 2020–December 2024 
implementation period 
Executing agency  Ministry of Education 
Implementing agency  ADB Southeast Asia Department, Human and Social Development Division.  
Consultants  To be selected and engaged by ADB. Number of firms will be decided 
based on the results of the road show. 
 
18 In accordance with ADB rules and procedures, ADB will competitively recruit INGO(s) for service provision, based 
on detailed terms of reference agreed with the MOE following analysis of priority gaps. Following competitive 
tendering for the first phase, ADB may consider single-source selection for a second phase, contingent on 
satisfactory INGO performance in order to ensure uniformity in the extended service provision. 
19 The EU requires submission of an audit report of the TA transactions by the ADB external auditor every two years.

ADB = Asian Development Bank; INGO = international nongovernmental organization; TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.   
 
19.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated staff instructions.20 ADB will 
engage the consulting services principally through firms. In addition, several individual consultants 
will be mobilized, including one program manager (TA team leader) and some key consultants for 
early startup. ADB will engage INGOs following procedures of procurement of non-consulting 
services to implement competency-based short courses under output 3. 
 
20.  Procurement. The TA-financed consulting firms will procure goods and services, in 
dialogue with ADB and the MOE and in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as 
amended from time to time) and the Procurement Regulations for ADB Borrowers (2017, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
21.  The delegation agreement with EU stipulates that consultants and entities from all 28 
members of the EU are eligible for contracts financed by the EU.21 To meet the requirement, an 
exception pursuant to Article 14 (ix) of the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank 
(the Charter) is requested to allow universal procurement for all prospective contracts under the 
TA. 22 
 
22.  Cofinancier requirements. The EU specific requirements  are stated in the special 
conditions of the delegation agreement between the EU and ADB.23 
 
E.  Governance 
 
23.  ADB will administer the TA, and thus the financial management, procurement, and 
integrity risks during implementation are assessed to be low. 
 
20 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). Output-based 
contract will be considered for consulting services, wherever appropriate. 
21 There are 14 non-member countries of ADB eligible for EU-financed contracts: Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Czech 
Republic, Estonia, Greece, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Romania, Slovak Republic, and Slovenia.  
22  ADB. 1996. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila. 
23  ADB. (Office of Cofinancing Operations). 2017. Administration of Cofinancing from the European Union. 22 
November 2017. (Internal).

7 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION 
 
 
24. The President recommends that the Board approve: 
(i)   the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  administering  technical  assistance  not 
exceeding the equivalent of $26,000,000 to the Government of Myanmar to be 
financed on a grant basis by the European Union for Support for Enhancing 
Education and Skills Base in Myanmar; and 
(ii)   the proposal in paragraph 21 of this report to permit the selection of consultants 
and the procurement of goods from non-member countries of ADB for Support for 
Enhancing Education and Skills Base in Myanmar.
